item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: @schoppik @BorisBarbour Agreed: hurrah for preprints + PubPeer. Ignoring outliers is not illegal (otherwise we'd have to ban the median). What's illegal is circularity. By removing more preselected "outliers" (middle row) one gets more "signal" (top and bottom row). They write: "It is fundamentally important to note that these peaks are erroneous because such a preselection process is statistically circular, summing noise in a biased manner to produce precisely the peak that was preselected."

item.title: Alexander H√∂lken
item.description: @kordinglab I'm not exactly sure which hypothesis you refer to. Is it the hypothesis that cognitive phenomenon A (say, choosing to sell rather than buy) occurs on a particular spatiotemporal scale? These hypotheses (of the type "this phenomenon of interest occurs on scale X") are usually tested by perturbing systems at nearby scales and observing how the phenomenon changes as a result. If such a change is observed, the relation "perturbation strength <-> effect on the phenomenon" is inversely correlated to the proximity in scale of the two systems. The following example assumes we're perturbing a system that our system of interest is actually coupled/sensitive to.Small perturbations to much larger- or smaller-scale systems either lead to small changes in the phenomenon, or its disappearance altogether, if the perturbed system provided one of the background conditions for its existence. This is exactly the relation we see between individual neuronal firing and cognitive abilities: Individual neurons die all the time without affecting the latter, same with synaptic rewiring.

item.description: Having two independently designed detectors is vital for cross-confirmation of any new discoveries made" https://home.cern/science/experiments.
